subject: Re: Using real data or test data?
msgSnippet: ... I had the same experience, although not so much as you. It was more a theoretical thought of me that one dataset for all tests can t be good. ... Let me
messageBody:
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger wrote:

> When I have used "one dataset for all tests", it has made incremental
> design difficult. The primary problem is relationships between entities
> in the data set. I might have to add a few Contracts to test the next
> feature, but then I need a new Agent or Department or something, and
> that affects the expected results in tests related to those entities.

> When I've done it -- three times was enough to learn for good -- the
> cost ended up being higher than expected and rose as the project went
> on, which is rarely a good sign.

I had the same experience, although not so much as you. It was more a
theoretical thought of me that "one dataset for all tests" can't be good.

> I think real data is good, because real data is often stranger than
> made-up test data. I think one dataset for all tests is a mistake -- a
> big mistake.

Let me explain my fictive data in contrast to real data.

For example I calculate ABC analysis in a batch program.

I will simplify the model:

Article
- id
- salesHistoryWeekCollection
- abcIndicator

SalesHistoryWeek
- week
- year
- soldQuantity
- price
- category {warehouse, commission or direct}

For every Article I calculate its soldQuantityPrice (soldQuantity *
price).

Then I rank them in a list according to their soldQuantityPrice.

The first 10% in the ranking list will be A articles. The next 20%
will be B articles. The rest are C articles.

Then I persist the ABC indicator on the article entities.

With real data I would have 65.000 articles.

So I make some fake data for my JUnit tests. I simply create 10
articles. Each one has 6 salesHistoryWeeks: 2 for each category.

For the first article (id 1) I set the highest soldQuantities and
prices. For the last article, I set the lowest soldQuantities and prices.

After the calculation I expect the articles with id 1, 2, and 3 to be
A articles and the articles wtih ids 6 - 9 to be C articles.

Its all in my hand. I even create invalid data, because I know that my
calculation doesn't need all the data which my validation rules would
require normally.

I even create and change the parameters in the database for my
calculation. For example in my first test case I set the params to
consider only article salesHistoryWeeks with category 'warehouse'.
After the calculation I check the result. It must be different than if
I had chosen all categories to be considered.

The dataset for my ABC analysis is as small as possible, just 10
articles. I only test the business logic, not performance or something
else.

Of course some errors still can be undetected. They are often detected
when run against real data. Then such things as NullPointerExceptions
can happen. I fix the bug and extend my test and test data if
necessary. Still I use invented data for my test.

I try to make my JUnit test automatic and independent, creating its
data for each test case or even test method and deleting them after
the test.

I consider testing with real data to be an integration test while
testing with invented data would be more of a unit test.
